Recently, we've heard of some big changes at several news organizations involving some of their most prominent journalists.
At the Washington Post, the founder of the popular policy site Wonkblog, Ezra Klein, is weighing a departure.
And the Wall Street Journal and the New York Times are both scrambling to set up dedicated news teams to replace journalists who have left in pursuit of more money and independence.
NPR media correspondent David Folkenflik joins us from our studios in New York.
And David, these sites - like, say, Wonkblog - they're called verticals in the news business, right?
What does that mean?
Well, what it means is you've got this digital presence.
You think of it as a site and a blog, but it's run by a team of people with expertise in the area they're covering.
And they're really relentlessly focused on the subject at hand but in, at times, an off-the-news way.
They may explain what's happening in the news instead of breaking what's happening in the news.
They'll find things that illustrate it metaphorically or with incredibly analytical data-crunching.
And they'll find different ways of getting at the problems and issues behind the headlines rather than the headlines themselves.
It used to be called the beat, right?
Well, yeah, except it's not just a question of who was named to what.
It's a question of what drove the decision that you're reading about on the front pages.
It's a little complementary rather than replacing traditional reporting.
So what's the state of play for Ezra Klein at the Post?

Well, he apparently - this has been reported by Huffington Post and now, in more detail, by the New York Times - he went to his bosses at the Post and said, look, I'd like you to invest many millions of dollars - the Times said it was an eight-figure request - to really build this up and expand what he did in explanatory journalism beyond the health care policy, economics and federal policy that he had focused on, to a broader array of issues.
You know, the Post has been in some economic trouble.
It was recently bought by a billionaire - Jeff Bezos, who founded Amazon.
Ezra Klein may have reasonably thought there was some money to play with there, but they may have said this is putting a lot of money on a specific project.

He decamped - Nate Silver, the creator of that blog - from the New York Times to ESPN, which gave him more latitude to explore his analysis and approach to sports and to entertainment.
Similarly, perhaps more meaningfully at the Wall Street Journal, you had something called AllThingsD - for digital; a familiar phrase, perhaps.
Kara Swisher, a reporter, and Walter Mossberg, the digital device reviewer for them, had set up a franchise where they had this vertical, this online presence as well as a presence in the newspaper.
But they also had an enormously profitable conference business that they had set up.
They felt they made profits for a dozen years for the Wall Street Journal without a heck of a lot help from the home office, and they decided to spin that off.

Now, how are these changes affecting the nature of journalism?

Many astronomers now think there may be a massive, undiscovered planet lurking in the far reaches of our solar system.
But right now the existence of this planet is theoretical.
So the hunt is on to actually capture an image of it.
One of the astronomers involved is Adam Schneider of Arizona State University, although he's only recently turned to planet hunting.
I am more of a brown dwarf person myself - brown dwarfs and low mass stars.
Brown dwarfs are objects somewhere between a small star and a giant planet.
And they have something in common with the putative planet people are looking for.
They give off infrared light.
And it just so happens that NASA has a space telescope called WISE that measures infrared light.
And WISE has taken whole bunches of pictures of the sky.
We have the entire sky to go through.
Schneider says that's both good news and bad news.
It's a bonus in that we have the whole sky, so we're not going to miss anything.
But that's also why we need citizen scientists because it's just too much to look at for one scientist or even a group of scientists.
By citizen scientist, Schneider means anyone.
No special skills required.
You go to a website called Backyard Worlds, sign up and start scanning the WISE telescope images.
Jacqueline Faherty is an astronomer at the American Museum of Natural History.
She says to spot the planet in an image, you have to find something that's shifted its position against a background of stationary stars.
Now, you may be wondering, why can't a computer do this?
Computer algorithms are not very good, the more and more stars that get involved.
The human eye helps tremendously.
It's much faster.
It can be very trustworthy.
But I have to tell you, spotting those moving items isn't easy.
I went to the website and tried, and I was terrible at it.
Faherty told me not to feel bad.
To be honest, I'm really bad at it as well.
But I want people with good eyes to do it because when they're good at it, they're really good at it.
Even if you correctly spot something moving in the images, it might not be the undiscovered planet.
It could be some other faint object wandering among the stars.
But Adam Schneider says you could hit the jackpot.
Literally anyone - you, me, anyone you talk to - can log on and potentially make that discovery.

Planet Palca has a nice ring to it, don't you think?
Joe Palca, NPR News.

Defense lawyers for terror suspects held at Guantanamo say the Bush administration wants to rewrite some of the evidence against the detainees.
The administration's request came up during a closed-door meeting this week with judges, defense attorneys, and government lawyers.
The meeting was to discuss logistics following the Supreme Court decision that Guantanamo prisoners have the right to challenge their detention in U.S.
federal courts.
NPR's Jackie Northam has been following the story.
Jackie, thanks for being with us.
Good morning, Scott.
And has new evidence come up?
Why and how do they want to rewrite some of the evidence against the detainees?

Well, the Justice Department declined to comment, but I did speak with defense lawyers who were at this meeting earlier this week, and they said that government lawyers told the judge that they wanted to review the evidence against the Guantanamo detainees and if necessary, update it, add any new intelligence that's come in.

You know, there have long been questions about the evidences against the terror suspects, and defense attorneys who have seen some of it says it's flimsy, that it's built on hearsay, and was supplied by people in Afghanistan who received a bounty.
The Bush administration, the Pentagon, have always maintained that the evidence it has against the detainees is rock-solid, most of it is classified, but that it can sustain any scrutiny.

Well, now that it will be analyzed by federal judges to see if there's enough evidence to hold the detainees, the government is saying wait, we want to take another look and update this evidence so we can put the best case forward.
And how was the request received by judges, and for that matter, defense attorneys?
Defense attorneys, as you can imagine, don't think this is a good idea and are appealing to the judge.
They say, once again this calls into question just how solid is the government's evidence against the terror suspects.
They also say it's a stalling tactic.

This request was one of several made by the government and the defense to the judge as part of this whole process to decide how to move ahead with these hearings where the Guantanamo prisoners can challenge their detention, and really, what those hearings are going look like.
Attorneys for the detainees want the judge to look at all the evidence and then decide whether a prisoner should be released.
The government wants the evidence limited to what was prepared by people at Guantanamo Bay.
And these are questions that the federal judges are going to have decide further down the road.
That Supreme Court decision, that's to allow Guantanamo detainees, in fact, access to federal courts, is considered a landmark decision.
But in your explanation, it doesn't sound as if changes are going to come quickly.
Well, that's probably true.

First of all, there are about 200 cases, and there are a lot of issues that are going to be challenged, such as presenting classified information, how much evidence can be presented, access by defense lawyers to their clients, security clearances, all this sorts of thing.
You know, the Supreme Court decision, as you say, represented a new chance for the detainees, but that's not going to happen quickly.
There was another Guantanamo detainee, Salim Hamdan, who won a Supreme Court case in 2006 that challenged the whole war crime system.
He's still sitting in solitary confinement at Guantanamo waiting for his trial to proceed.
It's not going to happen fast.
NPR's Jackie Northam.
Thank you.
